Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They are about to enter the main prayer hall for Friday congregational worship.
Story:
I stood in the lobby, smoothing my long sleeves and adjusting my scarf, feeling the familiar comfort of my modest dress. Today was Friday, and I was on my way to the main prayer hall for Jumu’ah, a time when I felt most connected to my faith. Just as I was about to leave, I saw a group of neighbors gathered near the elevator, their voices low and tense. The noise complaint had finally come to a head, and they wanted to talk face-to-face. 

As a neighbor, I knew I should greet them warmly, listen politely, and help ease the tension. But I also felt the pressure of time—Jumu’ah was about to begin, and I couldn’t be late. My heart pounded as I realized my modest attire, so normal in the mosque, might seem out of place or even draw attention in this setting. I worried about being judged or misunderstood, but I also didn’t want to seem unfriendly or dismissive. The expectations of both roles pressed in on me, and I hesitated, caught between the pull of my faith and the demands of being a good neighbor.
